posts.raw_content:
President of Serbia Aleksandar Vucic tried to enter a donor’s dinner for a Republican candidate, possibly Byron Donalds under a false name “Alex Vuchi” but was identified by protocal or Secret Service and was asked to leave.

After that President of Serbia faked being sick and returned to Serbia immediately. Few days later he visited Moscow for May 9th ceremony. 
 As President of  Serbia is a foreign national, he would have broken the laws of : Foreign National Contribution Ban which prohibits foreign nationals from making contributions or donations to US politicians and could put Republicans in jeopardy. It is extremely unlikely that a President of some country wouldn’t be briefed on US laws regarding political contributions.



However Vucic didn’t stop there. Trump and Kushner were working on a megaproject in Serbia , opening Europe’s first ever Trump Tower . The project passed and was ready to start, however Vucic then claimed that the document which allowed a previous building to be removed from the site where Trump and Kushner were to build a Trump tower was forged. This is obviously false but some on Serbian side claim that Vucic wants revenge for being kicked out of donor’s dinner. So he made up a claim that the document is forged to create a scandal for Trump and Kushner and help Democrats.

Previously, Serbian government was implicated in Dominion voting scandal , as Serbian centres and Serbian hackers were used to rig elections for Joe Biden against Donald Trump.

This comes extremely ungrateful as the USA administration was prolonging deadline for changing ownership of a Gas company in Serbia from Russian to Serbia because otherwise it would be sanctioned by OFAC. Biden’s sanctions on Russian gas companies included a Serbian NIS (Oil industry of Serbia) but Serbian government was given deadline to change ownership. They never did. Instead they begged OFAC to prolong it even longer only to screw Trump like this.

Sources for contribution scandal: https://telegrafi.com/en/Vucic-tried-to-enter-a-fake-name-at-the-Republican-dinner/amp/
https://amp.dw.com/en/serbian-presidents-foreign-policy-strategy-in-crisis/a-72447999
source for alleged forged doc: https://www.rferl.org/amp/belgrade-trump-serbia-kushner-hotel-development/33415075.html
source for OFAC sanctions waiver: https://www.reuters.com/business/energy/serbias-nis-oil-company-seeks-third-sanctions-waiver-us-2025-04-23/
source for dominion: https://www.lawrence.sd.us/AgendaCenter/ViewFile/Item/1044?fileID=16953

Instead they begged OFAC to prolong it even longer only to screw Trump like this.

posts.raw_content:
I see a lot of blackpills being distributed among us about the new bill. I understand the debt ceiling increase is a shit one, but rather get the spending on the right stuff rather than cut this administration off at the knees just for a potential next dem administration to inflate it again and claim all the savings from the past. I think it's a step in the right direction, but yes it's not ending the fed (which would be a hangover period for US).

So the following was generated by grok and it doesn't seem that bad:

The "One Big Beautiful Bill Act" (H.R. 1), passed by the U.S. House on May 22, 2025, with a 215-214 vote, is a 1,116-page reconciliation bill combining tax cuts, spending increases, and policy reforms. It now heads to the Senate, where revisions are likely. Below is a detailed summary of its key provisions, impacts, and controversies, based on available information.

Key Provisions

Tax Policies

Permanent Extension of 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act (TCJA): Locks in individual and corporate tax cuts from 2017, preventing their expiration. Includes lower income tax rates and expanded standard deductions.

No Tax on Tips and Overtime: Exempts tips and overtime wages from federal income tax, benefiting service and hourly workers.

Small Business Deduction: Increases the Section 199A pass-through deduction from 20% to 23% for small businesses, modifies wage and capital limitations, and closes state and local tax (SALT) cap workarounds for non-eligible sectors.

Child Tax Credit: Makes the credit permanent, increases amounts (specifics unclear), and introduces a $1,000 newborn credit.

Seniors’ Tax Relief: Adds a $4,000 standard deduction for seniors and removes taxes on Social Security benefits.

Business Expensing: Restores 100% immediate expensing for business investments, allowing full write-offs for equipment and modernization.

SALT Deduction Cap: Formalizes a $40,000 cap on state and local tax deductions, limiting benefits in high-tax states.

Clean Energy Tax Credit Rollbacks: Phases out credits for wind, solar, and battery storage by 2028, repeals hydrogen production credits for projects starting after 2025, and ends the $7,500 electric vehicle credit.


Spending and Security

Defense and Border Security: Allocates $350 billion for defense and border security, including funding for a border wall, 10,000 ICE officers, detention beds, and Customs and Border Protection enhancements.

Aviation and Infrastructure: Invests $12.5 billion in modernizing FAA air traffic systems and $12 billion to reimburse states for border security since January 2021.

Energy Policy: Repeals Biden-era methane tax, unlocks oil and gas development on federal lands, and promotes aviation fuel production.

Social Program Reforms

Medicaid Work Requirements: Introduces stricter work requirements starting December 2026, potentially reducing coverage for 7.6–10 million people by limiting eligibility.

SNAP Cuts: Reduces Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (food stamps) funding by $313 billion, potentially affecting 3 million beneficiaries, including children, seniors, and veterans.

Fiscal Savings: Claims $1.6 trillion in savings, partly through cuts to Medicaid and SNAP, though specifics on other reductions are vague.

Other Policies

Regulatory Reforms: Streamlines regulations to promote AI development and resource extraction, aiming to boost innovation and energy production.

Parental and Gender Policies: Includes provisions to empower parents and protect women and children, though details are unclear (often described as countering “woke” policies).

Firearm Tax Repeal: Removes a tax on firearm silencers.


Economic Growth: The Tax Foundation estimates a 0.6% long-run GDP increase from tax cuts but a $4 trillion revenue loss over 2025–2034, excluding interest costs.

Federal Debt: The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) projects an additional $2.5 trillion in federal debt over 10 years due to tax cuts outpacing spending reductions.
